Award.AwardTitle: RoL:FELS: Symposium: Evolutionary Biomechanics in the Era of Big Data, January 6, 2019, Tampa, Florida
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds a one-day conference at the 2019 Annual Meeting of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology, to advance research and develop new collaborations in the interdisciplinary field of evolutionary biomechanics. Imagine going for a stroll in a nearby park. Near the ground, a fungus slowly collects water so it can ballistically launch its spores into the air. Nearby, falling maple seed pods create air vortices, allowing them to remain aloft during dispersal. Up above, swifts and hawks scan the ground for food, their wings differently shaped for either maneuvering or speed. What do the fungus, maple tree, and birds have in common? Their motion - all biological motion, in fact - is subject to the laws of physics. Evolutionary biomechanics is the study of how the physical rules of motion shape the evolution of biodiversity, a field that is undergoing a renaissance due to major advances in imaging technology, machine learning approaches, and molecular phylogenetics. Novel discoveries in evolutionary biomechanics have important applications, including those in engineering and biologically-inspired robotic design. The supported one-day symposium highlights emerging trends in the field of evolutionary biomechanics. Undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers at the conference will obtain advice for pursuing diverse career opportunities, The major goal of the symposium is to galvanize new research and foster new collaborations in biomechanics.

All biological motion is guided by the laws of physics. The major features of evolutionary fitness - locomotion, feeding, and reproduction - are guided by mechanical laws. Thus, the physics of movement and the evolution of biodiversity are deeply connected. One of the major unanswered questions in biology is how causal and predictive the relationships are between mechanics and phenotypic diversity. This award will support a one-day symposium at the 2019 meeting of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology to highlight novel trends and discoveries in evolutionary biomechanics. Emerging leaders (of various backgrounds and ranks) in the field will discuss how they are using cutting-edge methods to improve our understanding of phenotypic evolution. New imaging methods allow the rapid generation, storage, and analysis of scans and videos. Machine learning techniques and crowd-sourcing platforms are accelerating the pace of data collection and pattern detection. Evolutionary analysis is being facilitated by Next Generation Sequencing and advances in comparative phylogenetics. Combined, these developments are rapidly elucidating the governing principles that causally, and predictably, link physics to phenotypic diversity. Students will be paired with symposium speakers in small groups, with the explicit goal of helping students plan their next career steps and forge new research collaborations. This award may help build an emerging interdisciplinary research network and encourage a new generation of scientists in evolutionary biomechanics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This award supported a special symposium on the intersection between physics, evolution, and big data at the 2019 annual meeting of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology in Tampa, Florida. The symposium took place on January 6, 2019, and featured 12 speakers from a wide range of backgrounds and career stages. The topics were highly diverse, and included approaches at the vanguard of the field, such as machine learning and dice-CT. The meeting-wide symposium was extremely well attended, and a highlight of SICB 2019. The specific topics covered were as follows:

Dr. Martha Munoz spoke about macroevolutionary principles that could be inferred from physical laws. 

Dr. Sharlene Santana discussed how dice-CT can be used to visualize and compare patterns of movement across deep evolutionary scales in bats.

Dr. Kory Evans spoke about how micro-CT approaches are opening new avenues for understanding key innovations, using fishes as a model system.

Dr. Natalie Wright discussed how takeoff mechanics can be used to reconstruct major biogeographic patterns of flight evolution across the bird tree of life. 

Dr. Christopher Martinez illustrated how biomechanical modeling in four-bar linkages can reveal evolutionary connections between biomechanics and morphology in fishes.

Dr. Jen Bright discussed how large-scale morphometrics (>5,000 species of bird) can be used to infer major patterns in form-function evolution. 

Ms. Brianna McHorse showed how biomechanical modeling can be applied to fossil lineages to reconstruct patterns of motion over deep time.

Dr. Vikram Baliga illustrated how convergent evolution in feeding ecology can be used to derive maroevolutionary principles of morphological diversity in fishes.

Dr. Emma Sherratt used micro-CT and geometric morphometrics to reconstruct the evolutionary history of microcephaly in sea snakes.

Dr. Ryan Felice discussed how massive landmarking efforts over large species datasets can be used to infer macroevolutionary patterns of skull evolution in birds.

Dr. Samantha Price discussed how machine learning can be applied to extract evolutionary patterns of morphology across tens of thousands of specimens.

Dr. Mike Alfaro discussed how crowd sourcing and browser-based landmarking can be applied to big datasets to extract repeatable patterns of trait evolution.

The symposium resulted in 11 peer-reviewed articles for an upcoming issue of Integrative and Comparative Biology. The issue is currently in press.

Broader Impacts: This award supported a mentoring and networking luncheon for students and postdocs. This workshop took place on January 7th. Prior to the meeting, students applied for the workshop. The symposium organizers created working groups of 3-4 students and one speaker based on interests and background. During the luncheon, speakers and students engaged in discussion on research and career readiness. Towards the end of the luncheon, students were encouraged to visit other groups so that they could engage with multiple speakers. In total, 38 students participated in the luncheon. Post-luncheon questionnaires indicated that students' self perceptions improved as a result of the event, and that they personally and professionally benefited from exposure to working scientists in an informal setting.
